title: Who will win the 2022 presidential election in the Philippines?
preds: I'm from the Philippines and I'm biased towards Robredo. Everyone in my camp is questioning the survey results although from my investigations, I do think that Marcos is in the lead but that Leni still has a huge chance of getting the win.
Recent poll shows more than a 2 to 1 lead for Marcos over Robredo from a reputable firm.

Big data heavily influences my final estimates. It could be a huge mistake, but I'm betting on it because social media, particularly Facebook, IS the internet in the Philippines. https://www.rappler.com/technology/internet-culture/hootsuite-we-are-social-2021-philippines-top-social-media-internet-usage/ POSTMORTEM: I made an inaccurate estimate. This is due to my own bias and my belief in an approach that has yet to be validated in Philippine situations.

I'm reiterating the same forecast even though there have been a number of recent statements by elements of the Catholic church asking for the parishioners to vote for Maria Robredo [1] as well as over 1200 Catholic church priests and bishops having a signed endorsement.  While the Philippines are a majority Catholic, I don't see this as ultimately effective since the elements of the church have thrown their support behind candidates before. With a more than 20 point lead, I don't see the clergy's support as sufficient for a win though they may cut the margin of victory by a few percentage points.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_Philippine_presidential_election [2] https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2022/05/04/2178710/over-1200-catholic-clergy-endorse-robredo-pangilinan-battle-truth
Marcos Jr looks to be unbeatable here.

Marcos has name recognition and is leading by a considerable margin in the polls. Public support for Duterte remains high plus duterte’s network can be used to pressure voters towards the preferred candidate. Robredo has a small chance given her rising pill numbers and the slight possibility of pro-democracy candidates aligning around her as they see their chances dwindling.

i think he (BongBong) would win simply based on popularity, also i found this wiki page going more into dept for votes https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_Philippine_presidential_election#Polling_for_president

I believe that since he's the most popular, "Bongbong" will win. I also believe in this phenomenon that those who campaign and show their name a lot more, then voters will be more likely to vote for them. However, since it is in the Philippines I could be wrong, but according to what I know, then there's a good chance it is him.

The son of the past president with VP who is the daughter of the current president is simply too much name recognition to ignore. Recent polling data shows that if the election were held today, the pair would have more votes than all the other candidates combined.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2022_Philippine_presidential_election

https://www.dzrh.com.ph/post/marcos-leads-in-dzrh-pre-election-survey-for-president Slight but noticeable drop for BongBong in the latest poll (12 March).   Will await more data, as he's still well ahead.

Updating based on recent polling and the fact that the potential hurdles that could have ruled BB ineligible for the election seem to have been cast aside. However, still plenty of time until 9 May, so leaving space for potential upsets.

I increased the probability of Marcos winning because of his domination of the polls, the media, and seemingly popular support. As a result, I reduced Robredo, Pacquiao, and Moreno's percentages accordingly, leaving Robredo with a lead over the other two. Additionally, more complaints have been dismissed surrounding Marcos' candidacy, making his probability of winning election higher.
The two biggest names are the most likely.

Even with the attempts to throw Bongbong off the ballot he is still holding a large lead in the polls. It seems to be the vocal minority that are causing his campaign woes. Most accounts believe that even if his candidacy is brought before the Supreme Court they will not remove him from running. Being that there is a chance that some unknown evidence could surface and force the Supreme Court to remove him from the race I must leave a 25% probability that he will not be elected. If/when the Supreme Court rule that he may remain on the ballot I would increase his probability of winning to 85%-90%. I would also increase the chances for PacMan and Isko as disenfranchised Bongbong voters would not vote for Robredo, a representative of the current administration, which has already talked bad about Bongbong.
The polls probably show a stronger lead for Bongbong Marcos but he is controversial in some aspects, so I cautiously come back down a little.

Marcos continues to lead in the polls despite attempts by victims of his father's regime trying to remove him from the ballot. Additionally, campaigning with the current President's daughter gives a sense of familiarity to voters and consistency. I came to my conclusions based on polling results and also Marcos success in the face of adversity. However, polls can also be misleading as has been seen in US elections which is why I have kept a wide variety in the probabilities for each candidate.

BongBong seems to be leading the polls, however it is still early in the election and he still has several pending petitions against his candidacy along with promises of appeals, hence the lower percentage than a lot of the recent forecasters who have him around 85-90%. Robredo seems to be his closest competitor. The polls currently have her at 20%. Christopher "Bong" Go has dropped out of the race so I left him at 0. Manny Pacquiao had about 8% according to the polls. As for Moreno, I don't know as much about his candidacy except that his rise has been fairly meteoric without as much of the negative attention that his opponent Manny has been facing for favoring his career over his congressional bid, so I gave him a higher percentage.  https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/philippine-leader-dutertes-preferred-successor-quits-presidential-race-2021-11-30/
https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/late-dictators-son-marcos-takes-clear-lead-philippine-election-poll-2021-12-22/
https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3163725/philippine-election-body-dismisses-petition-bar-ferdinand
https://www.npr.org/2021/09/23/1039763220/ikso-moreno-manila-city-mayor-the-philippines-rodrigo-duterte

Knowing cursory knowledge of Marcos Sr, I was somewhat confused why Marcos, Jr could be so overwhelmingly popular.  I suppose it shouldn't be that much of a surprise in the drift away from globalism, that a demagogue can whip people up.  Reading about his massive presence on social media also is what moved the needle up for me. https://opinion.inquirer.net/145364/what-explains-marcos-jr-s-popularity

"The Philippines Commission on Elections has rejected a petition to disqualify Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr., the son of the former dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos, from running in May’s presidential election. [ ] Four of the petitions have been dismissed and four remain outstanding. [ ] Comelec says that Marcos’ name will be printed on the election ballots, even if other cases remain unresolved. [ ] If Marcos was ruled ineligible after winning the presidency, he would be succeeded by the vice president."
https://thediplomat.com/2022/01/philippines-election-body-dismisses-petition-to-bar-marcos-from-presidential-poll/ It looks like he's certain to be on the ballot now, and even being disqualified after the fact would still mean he was elected for the purposes of this question, so it looks relatively certain given his expected almost 50% share of the popular vote compared to the 16% Robredo has in a distant second.
Original forecast was too low for Marcos on 2nd observation

For starters Christopher "Bong" Go has been disqualified so I would rank him at 0% probability. Then, according to the latest 2022 pre-election survey of Pulse Asia research shows Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr. at 53% meanwhile Maria "Leni" Robredo was at 20%. In addition to that Francisco "Isko" Moreno and Manny Pacquiao were at 8 percent. Finally with so many candidates I left the remainder at 9% for another candidate. Per The Manila Times, the survey had a margin of error of plus-minus 2 percent at 95 percent confidence level. (https://www.manilatimes.net/2021/12/22/news/national/bongbong-sara-lead-pulse-asia-survey/1826885) It is important to note that Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. bid still faces several legal challenges at the Commission on Elections.

Going by polls you'd think it should just be 100% for Marcos Jr; that and the fact that intelligence agencies have surmised that China is pulling strings behind the scenes, also he appears to have the closest relationship with Duterte who would be his VP if they both won their races.  It doesn't seem from my vantage point that the Marcos name is a drawback, short societal memory I suppose.  Moreno and Pacquiao both have fame on their side; the former an actor and the latter a boxer.  It's hard to gauge how important religion is for the average voter.  Most citizens are very religious, but the trust in the institutional church is lower.  Pacquiao's fame and most aggressively "family-values" (read anti-LGBT) may make him a dark horse.
I see now that Marcos has won his court battle, so I am updating up yet again.,
No movement for Robredo in the polling!
Latest developments in petitions to rule BBM candidacy out: https://www.rappler.com/nation/elections/bongbong-marcos-absence-comelec-proceeding-infuriates-guanzon/
Very ignorant early forecast. I'll update closer to the time.
Manny is loved, Leni is attractive and respected but tainted by Duterte. Moreno an outlier/darkhorse

I see Leni Robredo as a real contender given that she is a human rights lawyer and that she represents the part of the Philippines that have been devastated by a super typhoon this month. Further, she has gained the most followers proportionally compared to the other candidates, which could be a sign of growing popularity or a popularity that isn't being reflected by the polls. On the other hand, top contender Bongbong Marcos has the current president's daughter as his VP pick and represents not only one of two influential families in Philippine politics but also the largest regional population in the Philippines, which is Luzon.

"Between 70% and 90% of elected offices have been controlled by influential families. [] But even by those standards, this Marcos-Duterte coupling takes powerful clan politics to a new level, says University of the Philippines Diliman political science professor Aries Arugay." 
"Marcos' vice presidential partner Sara Duterte [] whose work is little known outside Davao, led in a presidential opinion poll this past summer can only be put down to the power of a famous family name."
"Marcos Sr. is believed to have amassed up to $10 billion while in office, and now his son (Bongbong Marcos) has been resuscitating the family's image with a sophisticated social media campaign."
"Among the many candidates for president, including a former police chief, the mayor of Manila and Duterte's closest aide, Robredo appears to represent the greatest challenge to Bongbong Marcos."
"Young people were especially susceptible to the Marcos rebranding, she said, because there were no standard history textbooks in the Philippines that explained the Marcos martial law years."
"Because our politics remain dysfunctional, our economy is still not doing so well, a quarter of the workforce is unemployed ... still a large number of people go abroad to seek better opportunities. So it is a revolt against their present situation, that's the reason the Marcoses are making a comeback."
"Marcos is also under attack by groups eager to have him disqualified from running at all. The Commission on Elections is reviewing four separate petitions challenging his candidacy. "
https://www.npr.org/2021/11/28/1058884480/duterte-marcos-and-political-dynasties-in-the-philippine-presidential-election "Marcos scored 53% in a survey by independent polling outfit Pulse Asia from Dec. 1 to Dec. 6. Marcos was followed by opposition Vice President Leni Robredo, who scored 20%, up from 8% in the September poll. Manila's celebrity mayor Isko Moreno and boxing icon Sen. Manny Pacquiao received 8% each. In the September survey, Moreno was at 13% and Pacquiao at 12%."
"Marcos faces multiple disqualification cases, with petitioners claiming a tax conviction in the 1990s bars him from running for public office. The Commission on Elections, which has dismissed one case that sought to declare Marcos a nuisance candidate, has asked him to respond to three other petitions related to his tax offense."
https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Philippine-elections-2022/Marcos-firms-up-lead-in-latest-Philippine-presidential-poll It seems the only legitimate risk to Marcos is the petitions at this point with Robredo in a distant second. Pacquiao is unlikely to crack 15%, which is respectable but certainly not enough to win. Moreno is floundering in 3rd. barely ahead of Pacquiao.  I'd be surprised if any of the petitions go through but it's too early to completely disregard them.
Weighting up based on the polling and looking back at the 2010 election
Name recognition is all in Philippines.
Mostly a guess, Manny Pacquiao and Francisco Moreno seem to have popular appeal, with Manny having more of a platform. Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and Christopher Go have more large scale political history.

Bongbong Marcos is the most likely to win because his party is in agreement with most policies of current administration
Further his running mate for Vice President is Duterte daughter which is a tactic approval from the current administration and Duterte popularity will translate to votes for Bongbong Marcos

Saw a YouTube video of someone randomly polling more than a hundred Filipinos on the streets of Manila. I was surprised to see so many Manila residents approving of Bongbong, someone from the Northern Philippines. Second place was Manila Mayor Isko. Put more points for Pacquiao since PredictIt still has him at #2.
Based on my guessing or my assessment

Leody de Guzman, Walden Bello
Panfilo Lacson, Tito Sotto
Updating based on withdrawal Christopher "Bong" Go.

Based on:
-  Reuters (16 Nov): https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/after-dust-settles-son-late-philippine-dictator-emerges-presidential-frontrunner-2021-11-16/
Marcos winning with 60% probability 
- Business insider: https://www.businessinsider.com/philippines-presidential-election-who-are-manny-pacquiao-bong-bong-2021-11
I could be undervaluing Sara Duterte, the daughter of the current President.

Right now, the leading candidates in the polls are Marcos, Moreno, Pacquiao and Robredo. I understand Go to no longer be a candidate, yet he has not formally withdrawn his candidacy. Still, the odds seem ipso facto lower for him than for any of the formal frontrunners. Of the top four, each holds a position from which history seems to indicate it's at least possible for them to become president. Here's a few other considerations - Polling seems to provide at least some information in Philippine presidential elections if you look at the last couple elections. - Of 15 presidential transitions in Philippine history, only 1 president has handed over to a candidate of the same party. So that suggests a starting base rate for Pacquiao of about 6%, who is technically a member of PDP-Laban—in fact, its president starting in 2020. But his presidency was disputed and it changed hands. Pacquiao's support is now around 15%, so I'll kick him up a bit to about 10% to start with. He is also one of the most famous boxers in the world, which I have to imagine is worth something- perhaps he's worth 15% after all. - President Duterte seems to be pretty popular overall, with estimates of his approval rating ranging from around 60% to around 90%. - If you look at the last few presidents, it looks like Arroyo had been the previous VP, as had Estrada. The sitting VP did not run in the 2010 election, but Jejomar Binay, the sitting VP, did, and lost. So of the past three presidential transitions in which a VP was a candidate in the election, two passed to that VP. That looks pretty good for Leni Robredo, the sitting VP, but 66% seems pretty damn confident, especially with her polling sitting around 15%. I'd kick her down to 40% to start with. - What about Isko Moreno? He is currently polling at around 23%, seemingly closing in on Marcos at about 25%. He is also the president of Aksyon Demokratiko, a relatively new political party that doesn't seem to have performed that well in previous national elections. He is popular as mayor. The Manila metro contains about a quarter of the population of the Philippines, but the city itself only has 1%. I don't see much of a reason to allocate more probability to him than his current share of the poll, so let's give him about 20%. - So. Bongbong Marcos. Friend of the president- per WIkipedia: "President Rodrigo Duterte has stated several times that he would resign if Marcos would be his successor instead of Vice President Leni Robredo." On the face of it, this would suggest that Duterte's high approval and this implicit endorsement of Marcos should go together. And indeed, Marcos has been leading the polls, topping out at more than 50% in one recent poll. But it's early, and in another poll he's dipped down to about 25%. He is a senator and the son of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos. He has been in electoral politics in the Philippines for about 30 years. There's one big thing to know about him and Leni Robredo: they went head-to-head for the vice presidency in 2016 and he lost—barely. So I'd give him about even odds to Robredo. That means we don't add up, with Robredo 40%, Marcos 40%, Moreno 20%, and Pacquiao 15%. My options are to scale everything down or to ask myself how wrong I'm likely to be in relative terms about any one or more of these candidates. It's also plausible that Go or another candidate could win; I'd like to give 1% to each possibility. I don't have a lot of other information right now, so I'll stake it here and normalize- Robredo 34, Marcos 34, Moreno 17, Pacquiao 13 -  -

Quick forecast before work. Leni and Bong Go seem to be the dark horses to watch. Bongbong Marcos has been the favorite and just below him Pacquiao. Political instability in the region, potential for corruption influences, and COVID make me less confident in reeling in a favorite.
Filipinos are so outthere that they want a heir to a crook and shoe collector back to repeat!

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/30/dutertes-chosen-successor-abandons-philippines-presidential-race
Go has hit the silk.  I'm expecting the Duterte kid to change her mind and stand for Prez instead of VP.  In that case, she wins.  I think this is technically illegal, a consideration which has never weighed heavily with either the Duterte or the Marcos clan.  If she stays in the VP slot with BongBong, it will be tough to beat them.   Philippine politics has always been tough to predict, though, so I'm probably wrong.   The continued political viability of the Marcos gang continues to bemuse.  I lived in the Philippines sixty years ago when BongBong's daddy was an up-and-comer, and even then lots of people were already tired of the family.  Still, the US harbours a lot of rabid fans of a truly dreadful former Prez, so clearly it happens.   BongBong is an easy name to make fun of if you've never heard some other Filipino nicknames.  And I am in no position to snicker, having once voted in cold blood for a guy called Bubba for Governor of Louisiana.  He was the good-government candidate that year (at that time they were allowed one per election, and he always lost; this may have been in the Constitution).
